head.title: Revived Stereotype of Hollywood Jews Abounds in Ironies; Anecdote in Question

hedline.hl1: Revived Stereotype of Hollywood Jews Abounds in Ironies; Anecdote in Question

block.p: Re "Stereotype of Jews Is Revived" (Arts pages, Nov. 7):
Re "Stereotype of Jews Is Revived" (Arts pages, Nov. 7):

Your inclusion of my name as the source of an undescribed "derogatory anecdote" for William Cash's inflammatory essay in The Spectator has occasioned a torrent of phone calls curious as to what the anecdote was and why I would participate at all in what is widely regarded here as an exercise in anti-Semitism.

Because relatively few people in Hollywood have seen the Spectator article, but have relied on your description for information about it, I regret that you mention me without more adequately relaying my account of how Mr. Cash quoted me entirely out of context.

I had cited the incident, of a Boston Brahmin would-be producer trying to dress in a more flamboyant, "show business" mode, as the only occasion in my decade in Hollywood when someone I knew suspected he was being excluded by some sort of ethnic cabal. In seeking excuses, the Brahmin, who had failed at other careers before failing as a producer, projected his bigotry onto others.
The point of the anecdote was to rebut Mr. Cash's perhaps paranoid thesis, and not in any way to support it. WILLIAM H. STADIEM Santa Monica, Calif., Nov. 8, 1994
